title: St Barbara slumps on fresh gold downgrade
text:
The lower production will force up unit costs; the mine was expected to produce gold for $1230 to $1290 per ounce, but each ounce will now cost between $1390 and $1450 to produce.

Ironically, Gwalia's production this financial year was supposed to be bolstered by about 14,900 ounces of production that was shifted from June 2019 to July 2019.

That delayed production was highly controversial, as it was announced just two weeks after institutional investors paid $355 million for new shares in the company and midway through an equity raising for retail shareholders.

As a result of the controversy surrounding the downgrade, St Barbara allowed retail shareholders to retract their offer to participate in the raising.

Despite the shifting the production from June to July, St Barbara's production was very weak in the three months to September 30, with Gwalia producing just 38,153 ounces of gold.

The weak output means the company will need to lift the pace over the next nine months to achieve its revised guidance, let alone its original guidance.

St Barbara shares traded as high as $5.07 in February, but have since halved to be fetching $2.54 on Friday.

Advertisement

The controversial raising in May was required to help St Barbara complete the $768 million acquisition of Canada's Atlantic Gold.

The company published production guidance for Atlantic for the first time on Friday, saying it was expected to produce between 95,000 and 105,000 ounces in fiscal 2020, with costs below $955 per ounce.

Atlantic produced 91,000 ounces of gold in 2018 at less than $800 per ounce.

Atlantic is expected to bring extra pits into production in Nova Scotia province in coming years, and St Barbara hopes it can be producing more than 200,000 ounces after 2023.

St Barbara boss Bob Vassie will address investors on Monday.
description: Ventilation constraints in one of Australia's deepest mines have forced St Barbara to downgrade production for the second time in five months.
